segments.text: OK, Paul Pye, F-Y-E, of Woods Hole Oceanographic.
George Woolard, W-O-O-L-L-A-R-D, of Hawaii.
And Maurice Ewing, E-W-I-N-G, head of the Lamont.
Well, it's called Lamont Geological Observatory, but it is an oceanographic institution.
Of course, he's dead.
He left them a couple of years ago to come down to Galveston University in Texas and had their geophysical lab down there.
But I'm thinking to myself, there were four that at one time were directing four out of the ten major labs.
came out of that small group.
They were all at Woods Hole.
They were all at Woods Hole at the same time.
We were all at Woods Hole at the same time.
And then, of course, Columbus Island, but he was directed at that time, so it doesn't count.
But Five, Willard, Ewing, and the Saw.
Now, did you all work for the Navy?
Yeah.
Together.
We worked for Woods Hole, Oceanographic, but they were paid by the Navy.
Navy contract.
Now, then, did they, too, go in private enterprise after the war?
No, those three all stayed in the academic field.
Well, that was one of the second questions we wanted to ask you, was what persuaded you to leave private enterprise and end up in the academic world?
Oh, the last ten years?
Mm-hmm.
Well, frankly, at that time, I wasn't unhappy with TI, and they weren't unhappy with me, but I got kind of fed up.
industrial world in the sense that, again, there's no, I'm not throwing rocks at them, but again, it's a person's own philosophy and interest.
And I suddenly realized I was running a $12 million division and it brought up practically nothing.
And so what future did I have?
I built it up maybe to $20 million.
And that sort of lost its interest.
to me, anyway.
And I thought, instead of having paper as my principal product, it would be fun to have people as my principal product.
It would be much more fulfilling and worthwhile.
So it wasn't a question of economics or anything at that time.
This opportunity opened up here at A&M.
Well, it had the oceanography department.
I was asked to take it.
So I had always planned somewhere down the road for too long to go into it.
teaching on a university level.

So I just moved up my schedule since the offer was a department head in oceanography, and not too many of those available, and accelerated my, you might say, retirement schedule from industry and go in the academic world.
Yeah.
You suggest, though, that private exploration should soon match government expenses in terms of oceanography.
Does this come from your experience at TI?
What was that quote again?
Well, that in an article you wrote, you suggested that perhaps private enterprise and private exploration should begin to bear more of the cost of oceanography and the developments in oceanography.
Does this come from your experience at TI?
You predict that government investment will drop in oceanography and that private investments will increase.
Yeah, right, because as we look to the sea more and more for raw materials and everything else that
the industry has to get involved more.
And so naturally, they should contribute something to oceanography.
Now, of course, a lot of the individual companies have been supporting not only our department with unrestricted grants and so on, but other oceanographic institutions as well.
So they are beginning to play more and more of their part and their role and carry their share in these activities, particularly the oil companies.
Oceanography Department, we're getting unrestricted grants and have been for some time now, ever since I've been here, from Humble.
And we've had some help from Amoco and the DuPont people.
Just to name a few.
So they are moving more in that direction.
Do you think one of the attractions for the university, for you, that is one of the reasons you appealed to the university as head of the department, was your knowledge of private enterprise?
your ability to secure grants?
I wouldn't be at all surprised, plus my experience with the government, too, having been involved indirectly in the government through withhold over the Navy contract and whatnot.
Yeah, that is a fact.

In fact, I came here at an era, you might say, when the university was looking for people the department has with industrial experience, because at that time, they also got Dr. Spencer in geophysics who comes from industry.
The dean of the College of Sciences, Dr. Zener, came from Westinghouse, the previous one.
And, oh, there were three or four other people in the middle 60s that came here to ministry.
The department head of the math department came to ministry.
Whom did you look for to bring to your department with you?
What sort of people did you try to hire?
Who were they?
And what did you aim the early department towards being, if I may?

Well, actually, I didn't bring anybody from industry per se into the department directly, although I have hired people since I've been here who came from industry, like Dr. Rezak, for example, who came from Shell.
But one of the first things I wanted to do when I came here at that time, there were nine on the faculty, nine or ten, I forget which, was to broaden it.
The emphasis had been
pretty much on physical oceanography, with the other branches of oceanography thinly represented and being more or less the handmaidens, I think, for the department as a whole.
So since I've come here, rightly or wrongly, depending on who you talk to, I have broadened and improved, you might say, the balance
between the different major branches of oceanography.
Of course, right now, it's not a numerical balance.
We don't divide the 27 faculty members by four.
We couldn't anyway.
We could not even.
But we do have strong chemical oceanography group and geological and biological to match an excellent and strong and well-recognized physical oceanography group.
Well, in terms of the government, would you explain your work with the President's Commission?
Well, the President's Commission on Marine Resources, etc., etc., was a culmination of an era, again, where there was a lot of visibility and a lot of gung-ho-ness for oceanography.
In an effort to get the thing into a position financially and otherwise, it might do more toward exploiting the oceans.
I use the term exploit not in the negative sense.
And the legislative history behind the Marine Commission goes back about ten years.

And it took about that long to get enough momentum and interest and visibility in the Congress and backing the Congress to come up finally with a bill which set up the Marine Council in one hand and the Marine Commission on the other.
And the purpose of the Marine Commission was to draw up a plan for the orderly and accelerated development of the oceans, with emphasis on the role, of course, of the United States
And the commission consisted of, I guess, 10 or 11 people who were appointed by the president, which Dr. Stratton was the chairman.
At that time, he was president emeritus of MIT.
Well, he still is.
And I was appointed the vice chairman.
And actually, there was only one other oceanographer on the commission, and that's Johnny Knauss from Rhode Island.
All the others were from various branches of industry or the government.
and two legislators, Congressman Mosier, and who was the senator we had on there?
So it was a pretty good mix of legal, political, sociological, and last but no means least, two people from the oceanographic community.

try and come to grips with a myriad of problems in these different areas that would naturally arise in trying to develop a plan for the orderly acceleration and development and exploitation of the ocean.
What it triggered, too, was we were supposed to come up with a plan to streamline oceanography in the government, because at that time there were about
40 or 45 different agencies, sub-agencies, and what have you that had their finger in the pie in one way or another in oceanography or ocean-related activities.

The theory was to find out about this fragmentation and then try to put together something that would have critical mass but also have enough clout so it continued to grow and develop and be of some good in the form of a single agency.
And the outgrowth of that was what's now NOAA.
one of the recommendations we made, which is in the Commerce Department now.

But it turned out that one of the difficulties was that not only was there proliferation within the government agencies in oceanography, but there was proliferation within the legislative branch and committees and so on, where there were about 40 or 45 agencies involved in oceanography in various degrees.
More than that, committees.

And if we'd had the guts to make another important recommendation, which we didn't, unfortunately, we would have said that not only streamline the agencies that are involved in oceanography, but streamline the congressional committees.
Because this way, each of the agencies now involve oceanography.
And NOAA isn't the only one, by any means.
But it has been culled down to maybe half a dozen or a dozen.
have to appear before a whole myriad of different committees to defend their budget and do what they want and hearings and so on.
So it's still a can of worms legislatively, even though otherwise it's sort of streamlined down.

Although since then, with all the hue and cry about ecology and environment, it's started to proliferate even more because we have outfits like BLM, Bureau of Land Management, that are in the sea that have never been in the sea before.
The USGS has suddenly got a pot full of money, and they've gone to see.
And now the EPA and the IRDA is in the act.
So it's about time, I guess, to have another commission to call the attention of the world at large, and the taxpayer in particular.
We're, again, proliferating the point with nonsense.
Did you serve with Treadwell on this commission?

No, at that time, Captain Treadwell was still with the Navy as the commander of the Naval Ocean Graphics Office, although we did lean very heavily on him and the staff for data and input that the commission needed from time to time.
He later on actually went with the council, the Marine Council, and he was there when he came with us.
The council was the governmental counterpart of the commission.
The council consisted of representative on a cabinet-level basis from each of the different departments of the US government.
They were involved in oceanography, and they were trying to keep the house in order of government agencies involved in oceanography.
Right, heard on that.
All right, then.
If I understand it, the purpose of the commission and the council, then, was to streamline the bureaucratic agencies who had some influence in the sea.
Right, and try and come up with a unified agency.
With one, which is NOAA.
Which is now NOAA, although it's by no means unified.

And the other thing was to come up with a plan how to do it and how much it would cost to, which of the plan which would be used to accelerate the orderly development, if you can do such a thing, accelerate the orderly development of the expansion of the ocean, the potential of the oceans, the wealth of the oceans.
for use of mankind in general and the U.S. in particular.
Was part of this to establish priorities then as to where the national interest would lie in the oceans, as to which would be the more important things to put the money into first?
That would be part of it, to establish priorities.
How did this relate to private industry?
What were some of the findings, some of the final outcomes of this as far as how much
stimulus should be given to the private industry, such as oil research offshore and other endeavors such as this?
Well, we had a special subcommittee, you might say, of the commission.
Not just one, we had five of them.
And one directed toward environment, environmental questions and problems.
And another one toward legislative problems.
One toward manpower.
And then one toward private industry.
That was the one I was chairman of, the subcommittee for private industry.

And there was a lot of talk about just how you could get private industry into the act and help it along without subsidizing it, like we've subsidized the railroads and the airlines and the barge canals and everything else.
One idea there was a group within the commission tried to push, but didn't get too far, was to have something similar to ComSat.
It's a quasi-governmental private organization that puts commercial satellites in the orbit for telephone communication and whatnot.
And I was one of them.
I was a ringleader of a ComSat for oceanography.
But if there was another group, for whatever reason, I'll never know, I guess, unless maybe we just claim that self-serving and self-seeking manages to squash it.

And the reason I say that was because there were a couple of people from government agencies on the commission, and they would foresee not wanting to have too great a role for private industry, because that might cut back their role.
And so the ComSat type of development for the oceans never materialized.
I think it would have been a big step forward, just as it has been for communications and satellites.
On the other hand, in all fairness, AT&T, since the development of ComSat, has spent more of their own money laying
good old-fashioned 125-year-old telegraph cables across the oceans rather than rely on the satellites.
I don't know.
It may not have been the fantasy I thought it might have been.
Did you make any specific recommendations coming out of the commission that you could quickly and succinctly
Well, let's see.
The commission started nine years ago, and it lasted for almost two years.
One of the first things we did was extend our life a year because we realized we could never solve the problems properly, come up with a plan in one year.
But that was one good thing about that bill.
It had a self-destruction, as a friend said on TV, that the commission originally had to go out of business in one year.
We did get a one-year extension, but that was it.
And the same with the Marine Council.
one of the few governmental bills ever written that is self-destructing for a commission of an agency.
But what I was leading up to was that it's been, well, five or six years or more since I've opened up, you know, a commission report and the particular report of the
committee on the private enterprise, so all I can think of is the generalities.
Do you have a copy of the commission report?
No.
Then I'll give you one.
I was just reminiscing about the concept of a way to implement the development and the involvement of the private sector into it, because that was one of the things that got so heavily involved.
This is the summary.
In addition to this, there are five other volumes, each one representing the summary of the five different committees I just mentioned, or subcommittees.
So I think you'll find in there what you need.
Oh, yeah.
The management of the coastal zone was another subcommittee, marine resources, global environment.
And there should be some way to... We don't actually have one for the committee on private enterprise.
It's... Well, it's...
It's mixed around 100 marine resources and around technical operating services.
I do have copies downstairs on the third floor of each of these others.
If you want to look at them, I think this is enough.
All right.
It's called Our Nation in the Sea.
Yeah.
Let's see if they get some more coffee.
I don't know.
And also that tribal language.
You were making some comments about my dialect before, but that tribal language is most interesting.
These are people in Washington?
Yeah.
Six words will do it, they'll never use one.
Yeah.
They all have things like...
Were there any particular congressmen who offered you, collectively or individually, proper support for the commission?
Yeah, well, Congressman Mosher, I think, was really the outstanding one, from a standpoint of a congressman.
And then in the senatorial side, there was Magnuson, I think he was, Magnuson from the state of Washington, and Kell from Rhode Island, two of the mainstays.
They were all very helpful.
So the Commission lasted for two years, you met once a month for several days at a time in Washington, and then brought in subcommittee reports.
Right.

Oh, then also we had hearings, but of course the hearings were not for the Commission as such, but we had subcommittee hearings all over the country, usually on Seaport and the County of Great Lakes and Seaport City.
Would you want to judge this effectiveness of the President's Commission?
Yeah.
It's all the blood, sweat, and tears I've put in this thing.

Its completion couldn't have come at a worse time because it was, after all, the Lyndon B. Johnson Commission in the eyes of the Republicans, although there were, at that time, two Republicans on it, Baird and myself, although I've since no longer claimed to be a Republican.
I'm an independent.
But be that as it may, if you can answer your timing aspect of it, it couldn't have come at a worse time because no matter how good it might have been the Bible itself, it was generated by opposing
party, in effect.
And had Humphrey been elected, I'm sure there was another person, if Humphrey had been elected, he would have used it as a blueprint in the Bible and implemented it to the best of his ability.
He probably is the most outstanding, most helpful person in this whole business.
I don't know why I didn't think of him before in that connection.
By then, when Nixon got through president,

He wouldn't have anything to do with it because, for the reason I just mentioned, what he did was set up a series of task forces to take our commission report and practically rework it and start all over again.
And this got a lot of people mad, including my wife, who wrote him a letter and said that
We spent $2 million of taxpayers' money and untold months of my time away from her, and she thought this was stupid to reinvent the wheel.
And I laughed at her when she wrote the letter.
I said, no, it won't do any good.
I said, you won't get an answer.
I said, you do get an answer if you're formal and say thank you for writing us a letter.
But she never even got a postcard acknowledging it.
So these guys did go and reinvent the wheel, and fortunately not to the extent of $2 million.
But we did spend a lot of time.
They did invite some of the commission members in as consultants and make comments on what they came up with and whatnot.

And so, in all due respect, not to Nixon, but to these cohorts that he had on these task forces, they did recommend to him to implement the commission along the lines, of course, that they had thought up and dreamt up in what now is NOAA.
The other thing that we had recommended, in addition to the NOAA type of operation, was also a NATOA, the Advisory Committee.
But we said that the Advisory Committee to NOAA should report directly to the president, so they wouldn't have any strings attached to it.
Instead of that, they modified that to having the COA report directly to the Dr. White, the head of NOAA.
And he pays the travel and expenses and the consulting.
So naturally, he gets the kind of
We party won.
No, no, but I'm into that.
I mean, he's in business and that's his job.
Although when I told him about it after it happened, he said, no, nothing like that.
Well, that's the postmortem, you might say, on what happened to the commission in detail after we changed administrations.
Now, it was a sad day for oceanography when Humphrey wasn't elected president, because he really would have pushed it.
I think Nixon's advisors figured how many boats do the fish have?
Forget about it.
Are you satisfied presently with the sort of support the government is giving the development of oceanography?
I don't know what I could really answer that because I'm not an unbiased, objective person when it comes to that.
Human nature being what it is, my answer is no.
You can say I have an ax to grind, but you just look at the numbers.
We're worse off now if we use 1966 dollars or 68 dollars in hard dollars than we were then.
Sure, the actual number of dollars that the government is putting in oceanography you can show is more than it was in 1966-68.
There hasn't been enough added, but the buying power is even equivalent to 1966-68.
As recently as 1970, our ONR contract was $1 million.
Since then, it's dropped off to $400,000 or $500,000.
And not only that, but we're fortunate to get that much because
Other institutions have been dropped entirely.
ONR put it the other way around.
ONR has quit funding a number of other institutions.
Same way with NSF.
They're right on down the line.
But what has happened since this big ecology and environmental bust has descended on us, the money is now going into not blue water or deep water oceanography.
It's going into outfits like EPA, BLM,
What does BLM stand for?
Bureau of Land Management.
And so from that standpoint, there has been a big increase in funding in oceanography.
Of course, again, it depends on how you want to define oceanography.
I mean, here we go in the bays and estuaries and it's still oceanography.
But it's not oceanography in the sense that we hope to develop the resources from the oceans that we had in mind when we drew up the plan for the commission.
And, of course, this has helped us as a department.

We probably, again, because we have access to our own submersible and have a unique capability, we've gotten, by now, I'd say well over a million and a half dollars worth of research out of these new outfits like DLM and the Marine Branch of the USGS and whatnot.
One of the reasons it's difficult to answer your question, yes or no, is because it goes into your definition.
What's oceanography?
Where it all comes from and just what the total oceanography dollar is.

If you want to include things on these new agencies in the oceanography, maybe we've gone up a little bit, but nothing in line of what was necessary to implement the plan that we're talking about in the commission report.

If I recall correctly, President Nixon, shortly before his rapid decline and demise, came up with a pledge for working on the energy crisis by pouring money into science to work on the energy problem that was supposed to be on the scale of the Manhattan Project.
And I'm wondering if anything ever came of that.
And I won't answer that question myself, but I wonder if anything came of that and what offshoots came off in oceanography for energy.

Well, what came of that, I think, is indirectly fed back in oceanography was a big pot of money given the U.S. Geological Survey to do work on a continental shelf in connection with finding oil and getting data to help regulate the oil economy and so on.
They've had more money now.
They don't know what to do with it.
Like Dr. Baumann, who used to be on the faculty, went with...
US Geos in Menlo Park as part of that recruiting program that they put on across the nation for people to work on the money they've gotten and the projects that they have since then.
ERDA is another one.
They've gotten quite a bit of money for, again, you might say if you want to call it oceanography because it is in the saltwater area.
which they didn't have before for this type of purpose.
I don't know whether you're aware of that workshop we have next year for two days.
We got a contract not too long ago from IRDA, which is a management contract for oceanographic research necessary to help IRDA solve their problems in the Gulf of Mexico.
And we're having a two-day workshop and bringing in about 40 or 45 people from the whole Gulf of Mexico area in oceanographic institutions and marine

orient institutions to, through this workshop, come up with ideas of what ERDA needs to do in a way of not so much a data gathering, per se, the way BLM and EPA and the others are doing, but solve processes involved in energy-related activities in the Gulf of Mexico, in our particular case.
Not only oil, but nuclear power plants, wave power and wave, and so on.
Professor Spilhaus seemed to think that environmental legislation interfered with proper exploitation of fuel resources.
Would you agree with that?

Well, it had and it should to a certain extent, but it shouldn't interfere to the extent of being unrealistic to the point where we throw the baby out with the bathwater, that we have a wonderful environment with no energy coming from it.
I mean, there's business about strip mining, for example, on land, and leaving it to the conditions that it has in the past.
I don't approve of that.
But on the other hand, the pendulum always overshoots and overreacts.
And what they're talking about now, to get the thing back into shape after the land has been used for strip mining, is just unrealistic and burgeoning territory.
But I feel strongly that they should put the thing back into some semblance of use for other purposes.
But some of the constraints that are laid out, like an environmental impact statement and so on, it's just entirely unrealistic if you want to have any energy at an economic price.
This last series of questions lead for me to ask for comments on four things from you.
What would you suppose the future is going to be in oil and the environment in terms of oceanography?
Do you expect more or less restrictions or more things asked of you in terms of offshore drillings?
Well, I don't think I can ask for even more things they're doing now on the environmental impact statement as manifested by agencies like the USGS, the Bureau of Land Management, and so on.
They have to do more than what we're asked to do now.
I don't mean actually in dollars or amounts, but I mean in additional things.
